lessons.title: What is Python?
lessons.content: Python is a powerful, high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and simplicity. It was created by Guido van Rossum and released in 1991. Python is open-source and works on multiple platforms, including Windows, macOS, Linux, and more. It supports multiple programming paradigms, such as object-oriented, procedural, and functional programming.

lessons.title: Why Learn Python?
lessons.content: Python is versatile and used in web development, data science, automation, AI, and more. It has a simple syntax similar to English, making it great for beginners. Python has a massive community and countless libraries, so help and tools are always available. Itâ€™s one of the most in-demand programming languages in the world. Whether you're building websites, analyzing data, automating tasks, scripting, working with IoT, or developing games and appsâ€”Python can help you do it all!

lessons.title: Python Syntax
lessons.content: Python uses indentation (spaces or tabs) to define code blocks instead of curly braces, making code cleaner and easier to read. Statements end simply by going to a new lineâ€”no semicolons required! This simplicity in structure allows beginners to focus more on logic and less on punctuation rules.

lessons.title: Variables
lessons.content: Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, you don't need to declare the data typeâ€”just assign a value and Python figures it out. For example, writing name = 'Alex' creates a variable called name holding a string value. Variables make your programs dynamic and reusable.

lessons.title: Data Types
lessons.content:
Python has several built-in data types that are used to classify values. Common ones include:
- int: for whole numbers
- float: for decimal numbers
- str: for text
- bool: for True/False values
Knowing the data type is important because it affects how data can be used or manipulated in a program.

lessons.content:
Decision-making is a key part of any program. Python uses if, elif, and else to run different code based on conditions. For example:

    print("You can vote!")
else:

This allows your programs to react to different inputs and scenarios.

lessons.title: Loops
lessons.content:
Loops are used to repeat actions. Python has two main types:
- for loops: used when you know how many times to repeat
- while loops: used when you repeat until a condition is no longer true
Loops help automate repetitive tasks and make your code more efficient.
